ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: It was a good course. Interesting when there were good guest lecturers, and not a lot of work. ProfessorNolan is the man.

Question 4: One hour per week isn't enough time for any kind of in-depth discussion.Question 6: It'shard to care about a landscape architecture project when you're standing outside in freezing wind for an hour.
Quality of speaker ranged significantly. Would appreciate more speakers with experience in city government or legal perspective.
An excellent introduction to land use planning!

For a 1-credit class, I feel this was very useful. As a 1-credit class meeting for 1 hour a week, it wasn't my first priority, so I wasn't always very well-prepared for class, but of course that's my own fault! The readings were good though, so I think if I read them more carefully, I would have gotten more out of the class. I look forward to re-visiting the readings from time to time.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Provided a very general overview of the field, without much commitment required.
Different instructors made the course interesting as they all brought different aspects from their work experience.
The variety of contemporary land use topics was excellent and cohesive. It was a great starting point from which to delveinto the other land use classes next semester.
size of class was good to make it seem comfortable for discussing / raising question during presentations
It was great to hear different guest speakers talk about their area of expertise almost every week, but then also to have Professor Nolon's point of view when he lectured.

Instructor Nolon was well informed and knowledgeable about diverse planning topics, he provided students an opportunity to participate and responded well to questions, comments and criticisms throughout the semester.The course content was structured well, with plenty of guest speakers, interesting and relevant topics to current events, and provided at an interactive pace. A great introduction to land-use planning.
All the case studies and applied examples of different concepts were helpful for understanding different examples and principles.
The guest speakers were great as were the field trips.

Guest speakers make for a dynamic course. Discussions at the end of class really bring everything together and allow students better understand the material of each class. The field trip was very well planned. Professor Nolon is really passionate about the subject.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Lectures/readings were often very repetitive and superficial. It's hard to take shiny development visions seriously if you've spent any time studying the problems of the development world.

caliber of speakers - include some from local city/state/federal government as well. also, perhaps talks could have been on more focused/narrow topics, finally, suggest saving room for discussion for 5-10 min immediately following each talk.
The lecture on green infrastructure could have been given by someone with more expertise in the area.
I enjoyed all aspects of this course.
It might have been nice to get to know each other (as students and professor) a little more in the class, to have a greater sense of cohesion/commitment to the class.
I thought it was a great 1 credit course.
Some speakers could do a better job gibing their presentations.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The course lectures and guest lecturers were all perfectly coordinated.
n/a
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Learning about land use is important for me because it is an integral part of urban planning and the environment.
I wanted to diversity my academic experience and learn about something I hadn't previous studied in an academic setting.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Seemed intriguing, related to my interests, and was an easy 1 credit.
I thought I might be interested in land use planning.
I wanted to get a clear update of current land use issues and what efforts are being made to adapt, particularly in the face of climate change.
I was interested in an introduction on land use planning, and the fact that the course was just one hour a week was appealing and seemed like a doable addition to my course load.
Out of interest only. No prior knowledge

Over the summer, had noticed myself being curious about a lot of different aspects of planning, including public transportation and solid waste management, so I figured this would be a good opportunity to learn more this semester.
I wanted to learn a bit about the subject and I did just that.
Great way to learn more about land use in the United States.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
I can't tell if the course was just unsatisfying or if I'm really just not interested in planning after all.
yes, particularly the knowledge gained from the field trip to Bridgeport!
Yes, absolutely. I loved the class.
Even more, what I learned from this class augmented a growing interest in land-use planning to the point where my plan of study has shifted substantially.
Yes, I think so, and I also took David Kooris's class, so I feel I got a good overview sense of planning concepts from these two classes.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: n/a
N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do the readings in order to ask questions to the instructor for that week.
It is an excellent overview of important current topics in land use with great curriculum support from guest speakers and field trip.
try to reach the speakers beforehand
Do it! If you are looking for an overview and introduction to land use planning without the stress of lots of extra work, this is the course for you.
John Nolon is very knowledgeable, the class is well-organized, and it's a good introduction to some major concepts in land use planning.
If you already know something about the course material it may be too easy for you.
